SP.P: What Part of my Conduct gives you Offence, Mr. Lovemore?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P:
Still harping upon that ungrateful String!—but prithee don't set me a laughing again. — Offence! — nothing gives me Of∣fence, Child:—You know I am very fond.— (yawns and walks)—I like you of all Things, and think you a most admirable Wife;— prudent, managing, — careless of your own Person, and very attentive to mine;— not much addicted to Pleasure,—grave,—retir'd,— and domestic; — govern your House,— pay the Tradesmens Bills, (yawns) scold the Servants, and love your Husband: — Upon my Soul, a very good Wife!—As good a Sort
of a Wife (yawns) as a body might wish to have.—Where's William?— I must go to Bed.—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: To Bed so early! — Had not you better join the Company?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I shan't go out to Night.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: But I mean the Company in the Dining-Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: What Company? (stares at her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: That I invited to a Rout.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: A Rout in my House!— and you dressed out too!—What is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: You have no Objection, I hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Objection!—no,—I like Company, you know, of all Things;—I'll go and join them:—Who are they all?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love,
SP.P: You know 'em all;— and there's your Friend Sir Brilliant there,

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Is he there?—I'm glad of it.—But pray now, how comes this about?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: I intend to do it often,

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Do ye?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Ay, and not look tamely on, while you revel luxuriously in a Course of Pleasure; I shall pursue my own Plan of Di∣version.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Do so, do so, Ma'am, the Change in your Temper will be very pleasing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: I shall indeed, Sir, —I'm in earnest.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: By all means follow your own In∣clinations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: And so I shall Sir, I assure ye (sings.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: What the Devil is come over her? and what in the Name of Wonder, does all this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Mean Sir! — it means — it means—it means—how can you ask me what it means?—Well to be sure, the Sobriety of that Question! — Do you think a Woman of Spirit can have Leisure to tell her Meaning, when she is all Air, Alertness, Plcasure, and Enjoyment?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: She's mad!—Stark mad!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P:
You're mistaken, Sir,— not mad, but in Spirits, that's all;—no Offence I hope.—Am I too flighty for you?—perhaps I am, — you are of a saturnine Disposition, inclin'd to think a little, or so.—Well don't let me in∣terrupt you; don't let me be of any Inconve∣nience.—that would be the impolitest thing— for a married Couple to interfere and en∣croach on each other's Pleasures, — Oh hi∣deous!
it would be gothic to the last Degree Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: (forcing a Laugh,) Ha! ha! — Ma'am,—you, Ha! ha! you are perfectly right.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Nay but I don't like that Laugh now,—I positively don't like it; —can't you laugh out as you were us'd to do? for my part, I'm determined to do nothing else all the rest of my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: This is the most astonishing thing! Ma'am, I don't rightly comprehend—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Oh Lud! Oh Lud! — with that important Face.—Well but come now, what don't you comprehend?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: There is something in this Treat∣ment that I don't so well —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Oh! are you there. Sir? — How quickly they, who have no Sensibility for the Peace and Happiness of others, can feel for themselves Mr. Lovemore! — But that's a grave Reflection, and I hate Re∣flection.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: What has she got into her Head?— This sudden Change, Mrs. Lovemore, let me tell you, is a little alarming, and —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P:
Nay, don't be frighten'd, — there is no harm in innocent Mirth, I hope; —never look so grave upon it. — I assure ye, Sir, that tho' on your Part, you seem deter∣mined to offer constant Indignities to your Wife, — and tho' the Laws of Retaliation
wou'd in some sort exculpate her, if, when provok'd to the utmost,—exasperated beyond all enduring, she should in her Turn, make him know what it is to receive an Injury in the tenderest Point—

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Madam! (angrily.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Well, well, don't be frighten'd I say, I shan't retaliate: — my own Honour will secure you there; — you may depend upon it.—You won't come and play a Game at Cards?—Well, do as you like;—well,—you won't come? No, no, I see you won't.—What say you to a Bit of Supper with us? —Nor that neither?—Follow your Inclinations, it is not meterial where a body eats.—The Com∣pany expects me; your Servant Mr. Lovemore, yours, yours. (Exit, singing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: alone. This is a Frolic I never saw her in before!—Laugh all the rest of my Life!—Laws of Retaliation! — an Injury in the tenderest Point! — the Company expects me,—your Servant my Dear, yours, yours!— (mimicking her) What the Devil is all this?— Some of her Female Friends have been tam∣pering with her. —Zouns! — I must begin to look a little sharp after Madam. — I'll go this Moment into the Card-Room, and watch whom she whispers with, whom she ogles with, and every Circumstance that can lead to— (going)

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Madam, Madam, — here's your Letter,—I wou'd not for all the World that my Master —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: What, is she mad too? What's the matter, Woman?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Nothing, Sir,—nothing,—I wan∣ted a word with my Lady,—that's all, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: You wou'd not for the World that your Master,—What was you going'to say? —What Paper's that?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Paper, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Let me see it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mustin.
SP.P: Lard, Sir!—how can you ask a Body for such a thing. It's a Letter to me, Sir, — a Letter from the Country, — a Let∣ter from my Sister, Sir.—she bids me buy her a Shiver de Fize Cap, and a Sixteenth in the Lottery; and tells me of a Number she dreamt of, that's all, Sir,—I'll put it up.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Let me look at it,—give it me this Moment? (reads.) To Mrs. Lovemore! — Brilliant Fashion. This is a Letter from the Country, is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: That, Sir,—that is—no, Sir,—no, —that's not Sister's Letter.—If you'll give me that back, Sir, I'll shew you the right one.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Where did you get this?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Where did you get it? — Tell me Truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Dear heart, you fright a Body so —in the Parlour, Sir,—I found it there.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Very well!—Leave the Room.

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: The Devil fetch it, I was never so out in my Politicks, in all my Days. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Love. alone.
SP.P: A pretty Epistle truly this seems to be,—let me read it.

DIV2.P: "Permit me, dear Madam, to throw myself on my Knees, (for on my Knees I must ad∣dress you) and in that humble Posture, to implore your Compassion."—Compassion with a Vengeance on him— (walks about) "Think you see me now with tender, melting, sup∣plicating Eyes, languishing at your Feet:" — Very well, Sir, —"Can you find it in your Heart to persist in Cruelty?—Grant me but Access to you once more, and in addition to what I already said this Morning, I will urge such Motives"—urge Motives, will ye—"as will suggest to you, that you shou'd no longer hesitate in Gratitude, to reward him, who still on his Knees, here makes a Vow to you of eternal Constancy and Love. Brilliant Fashion."

So; so! so!—your very humble Servant, Sir Brilliant Fashion!—This is your Friend∣ship for me, is it?—you're mighty kind in∣deed, Sir,—but I thank you as much as if you had really done me the favour,— and, Mrs Lovemore, I'm your humble Servant too.—
She intends to laugh all the the rest of her Life! This Letter will change her Note.— Odso, yonder she comes along the Gallery, and Sir Brilliant in full Chase of her.— They come this way, — cou'd I but detect them both now! — I'll step aside, and who knows but the Devil may tempt 'em to their undoing, — at least I'll try, — a polite Husband I am—There's the Coast clear for you, Madam. Exit.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Mrs. Lovemore, Sir Brilliant after her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: I tell you, Sir Brilliant, your Civility is odious, — your Compliments ful∣some, — and your Solicitations impertinent, Sir.—I must make use of harsh Language, Sir, — you provoke me to it and I can't re∣frain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: By all my Hopes we are now con∣veniently alone, (aside.) Not retiring to Soli∣tude and Discontent again, I hope, Madam! —Have a Care, my dear Mrs. Lovemore of a Relapse.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: No Danger of that, Sir, don't be solicitous about me. — Why wou'd you leave the Company? let me entreat you to return, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P:
By Heaven, there is more Rap∣ture in being one Moment vis-a-vis with you, than in the Company of a whole Drawing-Room of Beauties.—Round you are melting
Pleasures, tender Transports, youthful Loves, and blooming Graces, all unfelt, neglected, and despis'd, by a tasteless, cold, languid, un∣impassion'd Husband, while they might be all so much better employ'd to the Purposes of Extacy and Bliss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: I am amaz'd, Sir, at this Li∣berty,—what Action of my Life has autho∣riz'd such barefac'd Assurance? — and for what Reason do you think so meanly of me, as to imagine that I have not a greater Re∣gard for my Reputation, and for what the World may say, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: The World, Ma'am,—the World will justify you—she serv'd him right —they will all agree in it,—there will be but one Opinion about it, — that is, Ma'am, if the World should know it;—but our Loves may be as concealed, as Secrets undiscover'd yet by mortal Eye. — By all that's soft, it goes down with her like a Dish of Tea. (aside.) And so, Madam, since I have convinc'd you, —and since the Time, the Place, and mutual Ardor all concur —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Sir, I am not to be treated in this Manner,— and, I assure you, Sir, that were I not afraid of the evil Consequences that might follow, I should not hesitate a Moment to acquaint Mr. Lovemore with your whole Behaviour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P:
She won't tell her Husband then, —charming Creature, and Blessings on her
for so convenient a Hint,—she yields, by all that's wicked!—What shall I say to overwhelm her Senses in a Flood of Nonsense? aside.

DIV2.L: Go my Heart's Envoys, tender Sighs make haste,—
Still drink delicious Poison from thy Eye, —
Pant on thy Lip, and to thy Heart be press'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Zoons, this is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: What the Devil's the Matter now? (Kneels down to buckle his Shoe.) This con∣founded Buckle is always plaguing me.—My dear Boy, Lovemore,—I rejoice to see thee, They stand looking at each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: And have you the Confidence to look me in the Face?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: I was telling your Lady here, of the most whimsical Adventure —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Don't add the Meanness of Falshood, to the black Attempt of invading your Friend's Happiness. — I did imagine, Sir, from the long Intercourse that has subsisted between us, that you might have had Delicacy enough, Feeling enough, Honour enough, Sir,—not to meditate an Injury like this.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Ay, ay, it's all over, I'm de∣tected. (aside.) Mr. Lovemore, if begging your Pardon for this Rashness will any ways atone—

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: No, Sir, nothing can atone. The Provocation you have given me, wou'd justify my drawing upon you this Instant, did not that Lady and this Roof protect you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: But Mr.Lovemore.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: But, Sir —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: I only beg—

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, — Sir, I insist—I won't hear a word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: I declare, upon my Honour —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Honour! for Shame, Sir Brilliant, don't use the Word.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: If begging Pardon of that Lady —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: That Lady!—I desire you will ne∣ver speak to that Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Nay, but prithee, Lovemore.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: No, Sir, no,—I have done with you for the present.—As for you, Madam, I am satisfy'd with your Conduct.—I was indeed, a little alarm'd, but I was a Witness of your Behaviour, and I'm above harbouring low Suspicions.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Allow me but a Word —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: No more, Sir, I have done —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Brill.
SP.P: Let me but explain—

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Zoons!—I'll go into another Room to avoid you. (Going,.sees Mrs. Bellmour.) Hell and Destruction, what Fiend is conjur'd up here?—Zounds, let me make my Escape out of the House. (Runs to the other Door.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: I'll secure this Door, — you must not go, my Dear. Stops him.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: S'death, Madam, let me pass.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Nay, you shall stay, I want to in∣troduce an Acquaintance of mine to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I desire, Madam —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: My Lord, my Lord Etheridge; I am heartily glad to see your Lordship. (taking hold of him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Do my Dear, let me introduce this Lady to you. (turning, him to her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Here's the Devil and all to do! (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: My Lord, this is the most for∣tunate Encounter —

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I wish I was Fifty Miles off. (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Mrs. Bellmour, give me Leave to introduce Mr. Lovemore to you. (turning him to her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: No, my dear Ma'am, let me introduce Lord Etheridge to you. (pulling him) My Lord —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: In the Name of Wonder, what is all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: My dear Ma'am, you're mis∣taken; this is my Husband.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Pardon me, Ma'am, 'tis my Lord Etheridge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: My Dear, how can you be so ill-bred in your own House?—Mrs. Bellmour, —this is Mr. Lovemore.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Are you going to toss me in a Blan∣ket, Madam?—call up the rest of your Peo∣ple, if you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Pshaw!—Prithee now, my Lord, leave off your Humours;—Mrs. Love∣more, this is my Lord Etheridge, a Lover of mine, who has made Proposals of Marriage to me,

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Confusion! let me get rid of these two Furies. (breaks away from them.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: (follows him,)—My Lord I say! my Lord Etheridge! — won't your Lordship know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: This is the most damnable Accident! (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: I hope your Lordship has not forgot your Appointment at my House this Evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Ay now my Turn is come, (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Prithee, my Lord, what have I done, that you treat me with this Coldness? Come, come, you shall have a Wife, I will take Compassion on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Damnation! I can't stand this, (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P:
Come, cheer up, my Lord;— What the duce, your Dress is alter'd!—What's become of the Star and the Ribband?—And so the gay, the florid, the magnisique Lord Etheridge, dwindles down into plain Mr. Lovemore, the Married Man! Mr. Lovemore,
your most obedient, very humble Servant, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I can't bear to feel my myself in so ridiculous a Circumstance. (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: I beg my Compliments to your Friend Mrs. Leveit; and I am much oblig'd to you both for your very honourable De∣sigs.— (curtseying to him.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I never was so asham'd in all my Life! —

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: So, so, so, all his Pains were to hide the Star from me.—The Discovery is a perfect Cordial to my dejected Spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Mrs. Lovemore, I cannot suffi∣ciently acknowledge the Providence, that di∣rected you to pay me a Visit, tho' I was wholly unknown to you; and I shall hence∣forth consider you as my Deliverer.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Zoons! It was she that fainted away in the Closet, and be damn'd to her Jealousy, (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: By all that's whimsical, an odd sort of an Adventure this — my Lord, (ad∣vances to him.) My Lord, — my Lord Ethe∣riage, as the Man says in the Play, "Your Lordship's right welcome back to Denmark."

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Now he comes upon me.—Oh! I'm in a fine Situation, (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: My Lord, I hope that ugly Pain in your Lordship's Side, is abated.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Absurd, and ridiculous, (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: There is nothing forming there I hope, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: (apart with Mrs. Bellmour,) I begin now to feel for him, and to pity his Uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Pray, my Lord, don't you think it a base Thing to invade the Happiness of a Friend? Or to do him a clandestine Wrong? or to injure him with the Woman he loves?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: To cut the Matter short with you, Sir, we are both Rascals.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Rascal!

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Ay both! We are two very pretty Fellows indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: I am glad to find that you are at length awaken'd into a Sense of your Error. (to Lovemore.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: I am, Madam, and I am frank enough to own it. — I am above attempting to dis∣guise my Feelings, when I am conscious they are on the Side of Truth and Honour;— and Madam, with a true Remorse, — I ask your Pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Upon certain Terms, I don't know but I may sign and seal your Pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Terms! What Terms?—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: That you make due Expiation of your Guilt to that Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: That Lady, Ma'am! — That Lady has no Reason to complain.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: No Reason to complain, Mr. Lovemore!

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: No Madam, — none! for whatever may have been my Imprudences, they have had their Source in your Conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: In my Conduct, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: In your Conduct!—I here declare before this Company, —and I am above pal∣liating the Matter, I here declare, that no Man in England cou'd be better inclin'd to domestic Happiness, if you, Madam, on your Part, had been willing to make Home agree∣able.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: There I confess he touches me. (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: You cou'd take Pains enough before Marriage, — you would put forth all your Charms,—practice all your Arts,—and make your Features please by Rule;—for ever changing, — running an eternal Round of Variety: —And all this to win my Affecti∣ons: — But when you had won them, you did not think them worth your keeping.— Never dress'd, — pensive, — silent, —melan∣choly;—and the only Entertainment in my House, was the dear Pleasure of a dull con∣jugal Tete-a-Tete; and all this Insipidity, be∣cause you think the sole Merit of a Wife con∣sists in her Virtue:—A fine Way of amusing a Husband truly!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: Upon my Soul, and so it is.— (laughing)

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: O Gemini! Gemini! here's such a Piece of work,—what shall I do?— my poor dear Lady! (Crying bitterly.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Is the Woman crazy?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: Oh! Madam, — forgive me, my dear Madam,—I did not do it on purpose,— as I hope for Mercy, I did not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: What did not you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P:
I did not intend to give it him, I would have seen him gibbetted first. — I found the Letter in the Parlour, Madam, —I knew it was the same Letter I had de∣liver'd to you, and my Curiosity did make me peep into it. — Says my Curiosity, — "Now, Muslin, you may gratify yourself by finding out the Contents of that Letter, which you have such a violent Itching for." — My Curiosity said so, Ma'am, and then, I own, Ma'am, my Respect for you did say to me, "Hussey, how dare you meddle with what does not belong to you?— keep your Distance, and let your Mistress's Secrets alone."—But then upon that, in comes my Curiosity again, and says my Curiosity, "Read it, I tell you, Muslin, a Woman of Spirit shou'd know every thing."—"Let it alone, you Jade," says my Respect.—"It's as much as your Place is worth."—"There's more Places than one," says my Curiosity, "and so read it, I tell you, Muslin,"—I did read it,
— what could I do? Heaven help me, —I did read it,—I don't go to deny it,—I don't, I don't. (Crying.)

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Don't keep such an Uproar, Woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Muslin.
SP.P: And then, after I read it, thinks me, I, I'll give this to my Mistress directly, and that persidious thing her Husband shall not see it; — and so as my ill Stars would wou'd have it, as I was looking for you, I run my hand full in the Lion's mouth. Crying.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: What an unlucky Jade it has been! (aside.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Well have done, Muslin; this is too much.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Upon my word but she gives him his own.—I suppose you own the Truth of what she says, Mr. Lovemore.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Pray, Madam, does that Lady own the Truth of what I have said?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Sir, I am sensible there is too much Truth in what you say; this Lady has open'd my Eyes, and convinc'd me that there was a Mistake in my former Conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Come, come, you need not say any more—I forgive you,—I forgive you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: Forgive me! I like that Air of Confidence, when you know, that on my Side, it is at worst, an Error in Judgment, whereas on yours —

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Come, come, you know each other's Faults and Virtues, and so you have nothing to do but to mend the former, and enjoy the latter.—There, — there, kiss and Friends.—There, Mrs. Lovemore, take your reclaim'd Libertine to your Arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: It is in your Power, Madam, to make a reclaim'd Libertine of me indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Love.
SP.P: From this Moment it shall be our mutual Study to please each other. They embrace.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill. Lovemore,
SP.P: may I presume to hope for Pardon at that Lady's Hands?

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: My dear Confederate in Vice, your Pardon is granted.—Two sad Dogs we have been,—but come, give us your Hand,—we have us'd each other damnably—for the future we will endeavour to make each other amends.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: And so we will.—Ma'am, since my Lord decamps from before the Town, may I presume to hope—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: I positively forbid you the least Grain of Hope; whenever I take to myself a Husband, I must be convinc'd first that he will answer the Trouble of keeping him.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Brill.
SP.P: My dear Ma'am, by all that's—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: No Swearing—I positively will have my own way; you shall perform Qua∣rantine before I speak to you again.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: She's your's Man, she's your's, — she'll throw herself into your Arms in a Day or two.— And now I heartily congra∣tulate the whole Company, that this Busi∣ness has had so happy a Tendency to convince each of us of our Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, don't draw me into Share of your Folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Come, come, my dear Ma'am, you are not without your Share of it. This will teach you for the future, to be content with one Lover at a time, without listen∣ing to a Fellow you know nothing of, — because he assumes a Title, and reports well of himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. Bell.
SP.P: The Reproof is just, I grant it.

SP.SPEAKER: Love.
SP.P: Come, let us join the Company chearfully, keep our own Secrets, and not make ourselves a Town-Talk;— though, I don't know but if this Transaction were sent abroad into the World, it might prove a very useful Lesson. The Men wou'd see how their Paffions may carry them into the Dan∣ger of wounding the Bosom of a Friend,— the Ladies wou'd learn, that after the Marri∣age Rites, they shou'd not suffer their Powers of pleasing to languish away, but shou'd still remember to sacrifice to the Graces.
SP.L: To win a Man, when all your Pains succeed.
The Way to Keep Him, is a Task indeed.
